bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. OWENS:H.R. 2661.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:The Commerce Clause (Art. I, Sec. 8, cl. 3) of the UnitedStates Constitution provides that the Congress shall have thepower to regulate interstate and foreign commerce.[Page H5580]

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Trade.
Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

summary.text: Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to waive the requirement that Canadian vessels report immediately to the nearest customs facility upon arrival at any U.S. port or place or the Virgin Islands if, in fact, they do not anchor or dock at any harbor within the U.S. customs territory.

bill.title: To amend the Tariff Act of 1930 to waive the requirement to report the arrival at any port or place within the United States of a vessel of Canada if the vessel does not anchor or dock at any harbor within the customs territory of the United States.

item.title: To amend the Tariff Act of 1930 to waive the requirement to report the arrival at any port or place within the United States of a vessel of Canada if the vessel does not anchor or dock at any harbor within the customs territory of the United States.

To amend the Tariff Act of 1930 to waive the requirement to report the arrival at any port or place within the United States of a vessel of Canada if the vessel does not anchor or dock at any harbor within the customs territory of the United States.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Trade.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
